title: Towards enabling intelligent media servicers for a better world

author: Lyndon Nixon, Department of New Media Technology, MODUL University Vienna

But of course, I mean I can imagine if Google gets its act together somehow, make some nice deals with the TV channels with the people in this content, YouTube could become a very strong competitor to the traditional broadcasters.
Why go to the different TV channels when you know you can pretty much get everything on your one single YouTube or whatever channel delivery with added data services?

Affectively know, they're just thinking about different ways to try to enhance the experience.

Watching the DJ.

When I can, I just click a button on my radio set and I bought it for $0.99 from iTunes or whatever in the cloud.

Another thought of mine.
I grew up in the age of physical CDs and I'm just having a personal music collection.
I'm not too sure if in the future people will think that way.
I mean, maybe some people some people say Oh no, come on, we always need to see.
Do you need something in your hand?
But I think a lot of I have to say also younger people and myself are already not thinking in this term.
You know they're buying their music in iTunes.
They know that the music is there somewhere they can access it.
They don't care if it's a physical object or not, so maybe all of our media libraries in the future will be in the cloud.
We don't need to have anything physical at home.
And finally again, social media overtakes personal media.
So I mean, I've started listening now to last FM.
So if I want to hear music now, I just put on.
The stream on last FM I don't feel anymore if I'm honest.
I haven't bought music for few years now and I'm not afraid.
He says I have to do this summer time so that I know that last FM.

Another big thing.

What the show is called or whatever.

More to use other services.

While you're watching TV.

Because the money lies in user targeted advertising.

So where will media semantics be in 2014?
Maybe semantic research community, so multi ontologies.
So a lot of funding.

A lot of nice prototypes and showcases.
But there's not really anything that's there for the industry to say without using this.

But it's like you're not even getting used, so semantics will get used.
Companies want to say, is this something that has some sort of backing behind the standardization and we trust this?
Analysis And annotations is the big bugbear innocence, and in the community.
No.
I mean think about the number of videos being uploaded in YouTube everyday and you know we're going to manage to annotate all of these somehow, so this is a good research challenge.

Really, an analyst and annotation in parallel at large scale, because until you get the annotations in there, you can stop using semantics effectively to to have improved retrieval, or are mashups of media or whatever, and multimedia tools need to reach maturity.
